question_text: Classify the following numbers as rational or irrational: (i) 2 – √5, (ii) (3 + √23) – √23, (iii) (2√7) / (7√7), (iv) 1/√2, (v) 2π
explanation:
• (i) 2 is rational and √5 is irrational; subtracting an irrational from a rational yields an irrational number.
• (ii) (3 + √23) – √23 equals 3, which is rational.
• (iii) (2√7)/(7√7) simplifies by canceling √7 to give 2/7, which is rational.
• (iv) 1/√2 is irrational since the denominator is irrational.
• (v) 2π is irrational because π is irrational and multiplying by a rational number (2) does not change the irrationality.

question_text: Simplify each of the following expressions: (i) (3 + √3)(2 + √2), (ii) (3 + √3)(3 – √3), (iii) (√5 + √2)², (iv) (√5 – √2)(√5 + √2)
explanation:
• (i) Use the distributive property: (3 + √3)(2 + √2) = 3×2 + 3×√2 + √3×2 + √3×√2 = 6 + 3√2 + 2√3 + √6.
• (ii) Apply the difference of squares: (3 + √3)(3 – √3) = 3² - (√3)² = 9 - 3 = 6.
• (iii) Expand the square: (√5 + √2)² = (√5)² + 2√5√2 + (√2)² = 5 + 2√10 + 2 = 7 + 2√10.
• (iv) Again, use difference of squares: (√5 – √2)(√5 + √2) = (√5)² - (√2)² = 5 - 2 = 3.

question_text: Recall, π is defined as the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter (π = c/d). This seems to contradict the fact that π is irrational. How will you resolve this contradiction?
correct_answer: There is no contradiction. The definition of π as a ratio of two lengths does not require that the ratio be rational. π is defined geometrically and can be measured as a limit. Its irrationality simply means that π cannot be expressed as a fraction of two integers, not that it cannot represent a geometric constant.
explanation:
• The definition π = c/d comes from geometry and tells us that, for any circle, the ratio of its circumference to its diameter is constant.
• This geometric definition does not imply that the ratio must be a rational number; it simply defines a constant.
• Through analysis and approximation, it has been shown that π has a non-terminating, non-recurring decimal expansion, which is the property of an irrational number.
• Therefore, the apparent contradiction is resolved by understanding that a number defined as a geometric ratio can be irrational, and the rationality of a ratio does not depend solely on its definition.

correct_answer: To represent √9.3 on the number line, first note that √9 = 3 and √9.3 is slightly greater than 3 (approximately 3.05). Using a geometric construction or an approximate marking between 3 and the next integer, one can locate the point corresponding to √9.3.
explanation:
• Approximate the value: since 9.3 is a little more than 9, √9.3 ≈ 3.05.
• Draw a number line marked with appropriate intervals (for instance, marking integers 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, etc.).
• Identify the segment between 3 and 4 and mark a point approximately 0.05/1 units beyond 3 (or use a more precise geometric construction based on the method described in the chapter using a semicircle and perpendicular).
• Label this point as √9.3.
• This process visually demonstrates the position of √9.3 in relation to other real numbers on the number line.
topic: Representation of Irrational Numbers on the Number Line

question_text: Rationalise the denominators of the following: (i) 1/√7, (ii) 1/(√7 – √6), (iii) 1/(√5 + √2), (iv) 1/(√7 – 2)
explanation:
• (i) Multiply numerator and denominator by √7 to get: 1/√7 = (√7)/(√7×√7) = √7/7.
• (ii) Multiply numerator and denominator by the conjugate (√7 + √6): 1/(√7 – √6) × (√7 + √6)/(√7 + √6) = (√7 + √6)/(7 - 6) = √7 + √6.
• (iii) Multiply by the conjugate (√5 – √2): 1/(√5 + √2) × (√5 – √2)/(√5 – √2) = (√5 – √2)/(5 - 2) = (√5 – √2)/3.
• (iv) Multiply by the conjugate (√7 + 2): 1/(√7 – 2) × (√7 + 2)/(√7 + 2) = (√7 + 2)/(7 - 4) = (√7 + 2)/3.
